metadata.titleEn: SMAP soil moisture and vegetation optical depth product (9KM) using MCCA (2015-2024)
metadata.description:
Soil moisture is an important boundary condition of earth-atmosphere exchanges, and it has been defined as an essential climate variable by GCOS. Vegetation optical depth is a physical variable to measure the attenuation of vegetation in microwave radiative transfer model, and it has been proved to be a good indicator of vegetation water content and biomass.
This dataset uses the multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) to retrieve both soil moisture and polarized vegetation optical depth with SMAP brightness temperature. The algorithm uses a self-constraint relationship between land parameters and an analytical relationship between brightness temperature at different channels to perform the retrieval process. The MCCA does not depend on other auxiliary data on vegetation properties and can be applied to a variety of satellites. The soil moisture product from this dataset includes the soil moisture content in the unfrozen period and the liquid water content in the frozen period. Both horizontal- and vertical-polarization vegetation optical depth are retrieved. So far as we know, it is the first polarization-dependent vegetation optical depth product at L-band.
This dataset was validated by 19 dense soil moisture observation networks (9 core validation sites used by SMAP team and 13 sites not used by them), and the widely used soil climate analysis network (SCAN). It was found that ubRMSE (unbiased root mean square error) of MCCA retrieved soil moisture is generally smaller than that of other SMAP products.
metadata.instructions:
Data file naming method: <MCCA_SMAP_xxKM_CCFP_VSM_VOD_YYYYMMDD_V1.nc>, MCCA represents the multi-channel collaborative algorithm, SMAP represents the SMAP satellite, <xxKM> represents the grid size of ease grid 2.0 projection, <CCFP> indicates F-band (F is frequency) brightness temperature of P polarization was used as the core channel in MCCA, VSM_VOD is the product of soil moisture and vegetation optical thickness, <YYYYMMDD> is the date of the data in year, month and date format, and V1 represents the data version, which will be updated according to your valuable suggestions.
Usage method: Data can be read in various programming languages such as MATLAB, Python and IDL, and can also be visualized in hdfview and panoply. Please refer to the description document for details. We provide Python and Matlab code to read and plot data.

background: Due to the success of the SMOS (Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity) and SMAP (Soil Moisture Active Passive) missions, new satellite missions are on the horizon. The current and future missions can benefit from investigations that seek to improve retrieval algorithms that quantitatively map global soil moisture and vegetation optical depth (tau) from Earth’s microwave emissions. Soil moisture information is critically important in hydrological processes due to its relationships with land surface evapotranspiration, runoff, precipitation, and infiltration.
research objective: In this study, we explore multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches for the retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation tau, considering the payload configurations of current and future satellite missions (such as the Copernicus Imaging Microwave Radiometer, the Water Cycle Observation Mission, and the Terrestrial Water Resources Satellite) using a new set of ground observations.
challenges: It is affirmed that increasing the number of observation channels could make the soil moisture retrieval more robust, but might also limit the retrieval performance, as the probability that the model estimations will not match the observations is increased.
methods: Two ground-based microwave radiometry datasets collected in Inner Mongolia during the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River from July to August 2017 (cropland) and August to September 2018 (grassland) are used for this study. A multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) is developed based on the two-component version of the omega-tau model, which utilizes information from collaborative channels expressed as an analytical form of brightness temperature at the core channel to rule out the parameters to be retrieved.
dataset: Two ground-based microwave radiometry datasets collected in Inner Mongolia during the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River from July to August 2017 (cropland) and August to September 2018 (grassland) are used for this study.
findings: Results of soil moisture retrieval show that the multi-angular approach used by the MCCA generally has a better performance, unbiased root mean square difference (ubRMSD) varying from 0.028 cm³/cm³ to 0.037 cm³/cm³, than the multi-frequency approach (ubRMSD from 0.028 cm³/cm³ to 0.089 cm³/cm³) for the corn field. Except for in the C- & X-band combination, the multi-frequency approach used by the MCCA performs better (ubRMSD from 0.018 cm³/cm³ to 0.023 cm³/cm³) than the multi-angular version (ubRMSD from 0.026 cm³/cm³ to 0.034 cm³/cm³) for the grass field due to reduced vegetation effects for this type of cover. This study provides new insights into the design of potential satellite missions to improve soil moisture retrieval. A satellite with simultaneous multi-angular and multi-frequency observation capabilities is highly recommended.

background: Soil moisture (SM) is an important boundary condition of land-atmosphere feedbacks, and is identified as an essential climate variable by the Global Climate Observing System. Vegetation optical depth (VOD, τ) is a physical variable that describes the microwave extinction effects caused by vegetation in the microwave radiative transfer models and it provides information on both plant water status and biomass. Microwave remote sensing has good capability to retrieve SM and VOD, especially passive microwave L-band (1 – 2 GHz) because at these wavelengths the vegetation is semi-transparent, and the observed brightness temperature (Tb) is sensitive to the water content of the first few centimeters of the soil surface, and absorption and scattering have lower impacts, compared to shorter wavelengths. Current L-band passive microwave sensors on Earth-orbiting satellites include the European Space Agency's (ESA) Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity (SMOS) mission, launched in November 2009 with multi-angular and full-polarized observations and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's (NASA) Soil Moisture Active Passive (SMAP) mission, launched in January 2015 with full-polarized observations at an incidence angle of 40°. Most SM and VOD retrieval algorithms for SMAP are based on the zero-order solution of RTM, also known as the τ-ω model.
research objective: This study proposed a parameter self-calibrating framework for the multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) and presented a new SM and the first polarization-dependent VOD product based on the dual-polarized L-band observations at a fixed angle (40°) from the NASA Soil Moisture Active Passive (SMAP) mission.
challenges: Current retrieval algorithms often ignore the polarization dependence of vegetation effects. The retrieval performance is dependent on the uncertainties introduced by the auxiliary data. Since SMAP provides only two observations during an overpass, the degree of information (DoI) of Tbs can be lower than the number of unknowns (surface parameters, SM, and VOD).
methods: To reduce the usage of auxiliary data, the ergodic form of MCCA was implemented in this study, in which a series of SM values from 0.001 (unit: m3/m3) to porosity (the fraction of void space in the soil, unit: m3/m3) were set as input. The self-calibrating of Rou was carried out under two extreme conditions. For the first condition, which was assumed a smooth surface, the following procedure was followed: (1) Rou was initially set to 0 globally. Using the MCCA algorithm, 201 pairs of SM and VOD at H and V polarizations were retrieved for a range of ω from 0 to 0.2 with a step of 0.001. The bin size for DoI calculation was determined using all the 201 pairs of time series SM and H-polarized VOD. The ω value corresponding to the minimum DoI was selected as the result. (2) With the ω value obtained from step (1), 451 pairs of time series SM and VOD were retrieved using MCCA for Rou values ranging from 0 to 4.5 with a step of 0.01. The first initial Rou (Rou_init1) was optimized by minimizing the WDs calculated by SM and VOD at H-polarization.
dataset: In this study, H- and V-polarized Tb, and the surface temperature included in the SMAP Level-3 Radiometer Global Daily 36 km EASE-Grid Soil Moisture (SPL3SMP) version 8 were used to retrieve SM and VOD. The SPL3SMP is distributed by the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NDISC) and projected to the global Equal-Area Scalable Earth-2 (EASE2) grid with a spatial sampling of 36-km. Due to the heterogeneity of satellite footprints, 19 dense networks and 1 sparse network (the soil climate analysis network, SCAN) were involved to evaluate MCCA and the other five remotely sensed SM estimates, including eight networks sourced from the International Soil Moisture Network (ISMN) database, data for seven networks obtained from the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA), four additional networks accessed from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center, and the SMN-WDL network built in the Tibet Plateau, focuses on observing soil moisture, soil temperature, and freeze/thaw state. Sand and clay fractions were obtained from the global soil texture database (SoilGrids250m) for use in the dielectric model. Canopy height data were collected from the global ecosystem dynamics investigation (GEDI) Level 3 gridded mean canopy height (version 2), while above-ground biomass (version 4) was sourced from the ESA Climate Change Initiative (CCI) Programme were utilized. Total precipitation data from the ERA5-Land hourly data, converted from hourly to a daily sum, were also used in the analysis. All datasets were aggregated to align with the SMAP pixel grid size.
findings: The MCCA-derived SM exhibits the lowest unbiased root mean square deviation (ubRMSD, about 0.055 m³/m³), followed by SMAP-IB and DCA (0.061 m³/m³), with an overall Pearson’s correlation coefficient of 0.744 (SMAP-IB performed best with R = 0.764) when evaluated against in-situ observations from 18 dense soil moisture networks. The MCCA generates VOD values for both vertical and horizontal polarization, demonstrating a slight polarization difference of vegetation effect at the satellite scale. Both VODs exhibit a strong linear relationship with above-ground biomass and canopy height. The polarization difference of VODs is primarily observed in densely vegetated and arid areas.

Is the multi-frequency approach generally less effective than the multi-angular approach for soil moisture retrieval in a cornfield?
Is the polarization dependence of vegetation effects usually ignored in current retrieval algorithms for SMAP observations?

Disjunctive.Question: Which retrieval approach is more effective for soil moisture data collection, multi-angular or multi-frequency methods?
For evaluating soil moisture retrieval algorithms, which networks are more commonly used, dense observation networks or sparse networks?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the challenges faced in improving soil moisture retrieval algorithms using microwave remote sensing?
Concept Completion.Answer: retrieval performance limitations, uncertainties from auxiliary data, polarization dependence of vegetation effects, information availability from SMAP

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to obtain soil moisture and vegetation optical depth in diverse geographic regions?
Example.Answer: One example of a data collection method used to obtain soil moisture and vegetation optical depth is the use of ground-based microwave radiometry datasets collected during the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River in Inner Mongolia, which utilized multi-channel collaborative algorithms for retrieval.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when collecting soil moisture data using satellite-based observations?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge is the limitation in retrieval performance due to increasing the number of observation channels, which can increase the probability that model estimations do not match observations, as highlighted in multi-angular and multi-frequency retrieval approaches.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) used for retrieving soil moisture and vegetation optical depth?
Feature Specification.Answer: parameter self-calibrating, collaborative channels, does not rely on auxiliary data, suitable for various payload configurations, handles polarization differences, robustness in estimating parameters using the analytical form of brightness temperature

Feature Specification.Question: What specific attributes are measured when evaluating the performance of soil moisture retrieval methods?
Feature Specification.Answer: unbiased root mean square difference, Pearson’s correlation coefficient, polarization differences in vegetation optical depth, relationship with above-ground biomass, canopy height

Quantification.Question: What is the spatial resolution of the global soil moisture and vegetation optical depth dataset collected using the multi-channel collaborative algorithm?

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'vegetation optical depth (VOD)' in microwave radiative transfer models?
Definition.Answer: Vegetation optical depth (VOD) is a physical variable that describes the microwave extinction effects caused by vegetation within microwave radiative transfer models. It provides information on plant water status and biomass by measuring the attenuation of microwave signals as they pass through vegetation.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for soil moisture and vegetation optical depth using ground-based microwave radiometry datasets compare to those using spaceborne L-band passive microwave sensors?
Comparison.Answer: Ground-based microwave radiometry datasets, such as those collected during the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River, provide high-resolution observations over specific land covers (e.g., cropland and grassland). In contrast, spaceborne L-band passive microwave sensors, like those used in the SMAP mission, offer global coverage and are designed to retrieve soil moisture and VOD across various terrains and conditions, utilizing multi-angular and dual-polarized observations.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences between the multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) and other soil moisture retrieval algorithms in terms of data requirements and performance?
Comparison.Answer: The MCCA requires fewer auxiliary data and emphasizes self-calibrating techniques, reducing dependency on external data sources. It provides improved performance by incorporating polarization-dependent vegetation effects. Other algorithms might rely more heavily on auxiliary data, which can introduce uncertainties, and often overlook polarization differences, potentially affecting retrieval accuracy.

Comparison.Question: How does the performance of soil moisture retrieval using multi-angular approaches compare to multi-frequency approaches in varying land cover types?
Comparison.Answer: In cropland environments, the multi-angular approach of MCCA generally outperforms the multi-frequency approach, offering better performance metrics such as lower ubRMSD. However, for grassland covers, the multi-frequency approach can yield superior results, likely due to reduced vegetation effects, highlighting the need for different approaches based on land cover characteristics.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches improve the robustness of soil moisture retrieval datasets, and what are the potential trade-offs?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches can improve the robustness of soil moisture retrieval by increasing the number of observation channels, thus enhancing the dataset's resilience against errors. However, the trade-off may include increased complexity and potential limitations in retrieval performance, as the probability that model estimations will not match observations could rise.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the heterogeneity of satellite footprints be accounted for when validating soil moisture datasets using dense observation networks?
Interpretation.Answer: The heterogeneity of satellite footprints can be accounted for by involving multiple dense networks in the validation process, which helps to align the datasets with the satellite pixel grid size. Using diverse sources, including international soil moisture networks and various remote sensing estimates, can help to capture the spatial variability and improve the accuracy and reliability of soil moisture datasets.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the precision of soil moisture retrieval algorithms to vary across different satellite missions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The precision of soil moisture retrieval algorithms can vary across different satellite missions due to factors such as the number of observation channels, payload configurations, and the retrieval models used. The balance between the number of channels and the robustness of retrievals, as well as the self-calibrating capabilities of algorithms, significantly affects precision.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying causes that lead to polarization differences in vegetation optical depth observed at the satellite scale?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Polarization differences in vegetation optical depth observed at the satellite scale are primarily caused by the varying effects of vegetation density and moisture on microwave emissions. Densely vegetated and arid areas tend to exhibit more pronounced polarization differences due to the interaction of microwave signals with vegetation structure and moisture content.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the inclusion of polarization-dependent vegetation optical depth data affect the development of future satellite missions' data collection strategies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating polarization-dependent vegetation optical depth data can provide new insights into vegetation effects at the satellite scale, potentially influencing the design of future satellite missions to include capabilities for simultaneous multi-angular and multi-frequency observations. This could lead to more accurate soil moisture and vegetation data retrievals, particularly in densely vegetated and arid areas where polarization differences are more pronounced.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the expected consequences on data accuracy and reliability when utilizing ground-based microwave radiometry datasets in soil moisture experiments?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing ground-based microwave radiometry datasets in soil moisture experiments can enhance data accuracy and reliability. The datasets provide critical baseline observations for developing and validating algorithms like the MCCA, which have shown better performance in soil moisture retrieval by reducing the effects of vegetation and improving the unbiased root mean square difference (ubRMSD) across different field conditions such as cropland and grassland.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of employing a multi-channel collaborative algorithm in the retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth from satellite observations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to improve the retrieval accuracy of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth by using a multi-channel collaborative algorithm that leverages self-constrained relationships between parameters and theoretical conversion relationships between channels, thus eliminating the need for auxiliary data and adapting to various payload configurations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are utilized to retrieve soil moisture and vegetation optical depth from satellite microwave emissions, considering the payload configurations of current and future satellite missions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) is developed, which utilizes information from collaborative channels expressed as an analytical form of brightness temperature at the core channel to rule out the parameters to be retrieved. This approach considers multi-angular and multi-frequency configurations for retrieval, using datasets collected from ground-based microwave radiometry experiments.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the polarization dependence of vegetation effects be accounted for in soil moisture and vegetation optical depth retrieval algorithms?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To address the polarization dependence, a parameter self-calibrating framework for the multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) was proposed, utilizing dual-polarized L-band observations at a fixed angle. This involves self-calibrating parameters under different surface conditions to optimize retrieval performance and minimize uncertainties introduced by auxiliary data.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth using satellite data without relying heavily on auxiliary data?
Enablement.Answer: In the field, the multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) is implemented to reduce the usage of auxiliary data by utilizing the self-calibrating framework that allows the retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth from satellite data. This approach uses the ergodic form of MCCA to set a series of soil moisture values as input and self-calibrates under extreme conditions to optimize retrievals.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of ground-based microwave radiometry datasets contribute to improving the accuracy of soil moisture retrieval in satellite missions?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of ground-based microwave radiometry datasets, such as those collected during the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River, enables the enhancement of soil moisture retrieval accuracy by providing critical observational data that support the development of the multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA), which is used in satellite missions.

Expectation.Question: Why might expanding the number of observation channels in satellite missions potentially limit the retrieval performance of soil moisture data?
Expectation.Answer: Increasing the number of observation channels could make the soil moisture retrieval more robust, but might also limit the retrieval performance as it increases the probability that the model estimations will not match the observations.

Expectation.Question: Why is it important to reduce the usage of auxiliary data in retrieval algorithms for soil moisture and vegetation optical depth?
Expectation.Answer: Reducing the usage of auxiliary data is important because the retrieval performance is dependent on the uncertainties introduced by such data. Since SMAP provides limited observations during an overpass, minimizing auxiliary data helps to better manage the degree of information and improve the retrieval accuracy of surface parameters, soil moisture, and vegetation optical depth.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you consider multi-channel collaborative algorithms in improving the accuracy of soil moisture retrieval when compared to traditional methods?
Judgmental.Answer: The multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) is considered effective in improving the accuracy of soil moisture retrieval. It generally shows better performance with an unbiased root mean square difference (ubRMSD) ranging from 0.028 cm³/cm³ to 0.037 cm³/cm³ for certain conditions, outperforming traditional multi-frequency approaches, especially in environments with dense vegetation.

Judgmental.Question: What are the major methodological challenges when integrating multi-angular and multi-frequency observations for soil moisture and vegetation optical depth retrieval?
Judgmental.Answer: A major methodological challenge lies in balancing the robustness of soil moisture retrieval with the complexity introduced by increased observation channels, which can limit performance. Additionally, ensuring that the degree of information from observations matches the number of unknown parameters is a challenge, especially since SMAP provides limited observations during an overpass.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are potential strategies to enhance dataset validation for soil moisture and vegetation optical depth products on a global scale?
Judgmental.Answer: Enhancing dataset validation can involve expanding the number and diversity of dense observation networks globally. Utilizing data from international networks like the International Soil Moisture Network (ISMN) and integrating auxiliary datasets such as canopy height from GEDI and above-ground biomass from ESA's CCI Programme could improve validation. Additionally, comparing datasets against in-situ observations from diverse climatic and vegetation conditions may also enhance validation.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand why utilizing multiple observation channels in satellite missions could potentially limit the retrieval performance for soil moisture.
Assertion.Answer: The use of multiple observation channels can increase the robustness of soil moisture retrievals by providing more data points, but it also raises the chances that model estimations will not match the observations, thus potentially limiting retrieval performance.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how a multi-channel collaborative algorithm can function effectively without relying on auxiliary data.
Assertion.Answer: The multi-channel collaborative algorithm leverages the self-constraining relationships between parameters and the theoretical transformation relationships between channels to retrieve surface parameters, minimizing the dependence on auxiliary data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges associated with soil moisture retrieval when using multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches in remote sensing.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges in soil moisture retrieval using multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches include the potential limitations in retrieval performance due to an increased number of observation channels, which may lead to model estimations not matching observations. Additionally, the polarization dependence of vegetation effects is often ignored, and there is a dependency on auxiliary data which introduces uncertainties.
